z:row.TitlePrimary: NATURAL CONVECTION IN VERTICAL ENCLOSURES PARTITIONED AT DIFFERENT ANGLES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Natural Convection in Enclosures - 1986. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
z:row.Keyword: HEAT TRANSFER -- Convection|MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES - Finite Difference Method|INTERFEROMETRY
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Natural convection heat transfer in vertical enclosures partitioned at different angles has been studied experimentally and numerically using interferometric and finite difference techniques, respectively. The effects of Rayleigh number, partition angle, and aspect ratio on both the local and average heat transfer coefficients have been determined. The Rayleigh number range tested was up to 7 multiplied by 10**4, and the aspect ratio varied between 0. 25 to 4. The angles of partition with respect to the hot plate were 30, 45, 60, 90, 120, 135, and 150 degrees. The results indicate that the convective heat transfer is a strong function of the aspect ratio between 0. 25 to 4 for all the test partition angles. As the partition angle varied from 30 to 150 degrees, the heat transfer first increased and then started to decrease after obtaining a maximum at about 120 degrees.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: INTERFEROMETRIC STUDY OF FREE, FORCED AND MIXED CONVECTION HEAT TRANSFER FROM HEATED VERTICAL CYLINDERS IN AIR WITH OPPOSING BUOYANT AND INERTIAL FORCES
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fundamentals of Forced and Mixed Convection. Presented at the 23rd National Heat Transfer Conference.
z:row.TitleTertiary: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
z:row.Keyword: HEAT TRANSFER -- Convection|CYLINDERS - Heat Transfer|FLOW OF FLUIDS - Transition Flow|NUCLEAR REACTORS - Loss of Coolant Accident
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Mechanical Engineering Dep, Madison, WI, USA, USA
z:row.Abstract: An external forced-, free-, and mixed convection heat transfer, with opposing buoyant and inertial forces from heated vertical cylinders in air, was interferometrically investigated. The mixed convection behavior, which appears during the transition from downward forced flow to free convection, was simulated by quasi-unsteady state conditions. The transition was characterized by five distinct heat and flow regimes. The local Nusselt numbers are presented in graphical form for each of these regimes.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: DO THE FORCED FLOW AND SUBCOOLING OF THE COOLANT AFFECT THE MINIMUM FILM BOILING POINT?
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fundamentals of Phase Change: Boiling and Condensation. Presented at the Winter Annual Meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.
z:row.Keyword: FLOW OF FLUIDS -- Films|HEAT TRANSFER - Boiling Liquids|LIQUIDS - Velocity Measurement|FREONS - Applications|THERMOCOUPLES
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Dep of Mechanical Engineering, Madison, WI, USA, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effects of liquid flow velocity and subcooling on the minimum film boiling point (MFBP) of small spheres were investigated. The liquid Reynolds number ranged from 0 to 3500. A limited photographic study was conducted. The experimental data indicated quite noticeable effects of liquid speed and subcooling on the MFBP. The experimental data were correlated to single out the effect of forced convection on the MFBP in the subcooled and saturated cases. The correlated data, along with the examination of the possible events taking place in the liquid and vapor boundary layers, were then used to explain the observed effects of the liquid speed on the minimum film boiling wall superheat.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: LIQUID FLOW VELOCITY; MINIMUM FILM BOILING POINT (MFBP); LIQUID REYNOLDS NUMBER; VAPOR BOUNDARY LAYERS; SUPERHEAT

z:row.TitlePrimary: CONVECTIVE COOLING OF SIMULATED CORE DEBRIS BEDS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Post Accident Debris Cooling, Proceedings of the 5th Post Accident Heat Removal Information Exchange Meeting.
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Nuclear Engineering Dep, Madison, Wis, USA
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: CONVECTIVE COOLING; DEBRIS BEDS; PARTICLE TRACING TECHNIQUES; MACH-ZEHNDER INTERFEROMETRY; COMPUTER CODE COMMIX-1A; FLOW PATTERNS

z:row.TitlePrimary: CONVECTIVE HEAT TRANSFER IN VEE-TROUGH LINEAR CONCENTRATORS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: Natural convection heat-transfer coefficients were experimentally determined for trough-type collectors. The effects of Rayleigh number, tilt angle, and ideal concentration ratio on the Nusselt number have been experimentally determined over ranges representative of collector operation. The experimental results are supported by finite element solutions to the governing equations. The convective losses are compared to those for conventional flat plate collectors.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: IMPROVED INTERFEROMETRIC TECHNIQUE FOR MEASURING BINARY DIFFUSION COEFFICIENTS
z:row.TitleSecondary: Heat Transfer 1982, Proceedings of the 7th International Heat Transfer Conference. Volume 4: General Papers: Pool Boiling, Flow Boiling, Measuring Techniques.
z:row.TitleTertiary: Heat Transfer, Proceedings of the International Heat Transfer Conference
z:row.Publisher: Hemisphere Publ Corp, Washington, DC, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: BINARY DIFFUSION; INTERFEROMETRY; GASES; LIQUIDS; TEMPERATURE MEASUREMENTS

z:row.TitlePrimary: EFFECT OF THERMAL WALL PROPERTIES ON NATURAL CONVECTION IN INCLINED RECTANGULAR CELLS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Heat Transfer, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: The effects of cell wall thickness and thermal conductivity in natural convective heat transfer within inclined rectangular cells was studied. In this study, the effect of wall conductivity and wall thickness are presented in the form of correlations. Comparison with available experimental and numerical work of other authors is also given.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Interferometric investigations of convection in slat, flat plate and vee-corrugated solar collectors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Solar Energy International Progress. Proceedings of the International Symposium-Workshop on Solar Energy, 16-22 June 1978
z:row.TitleTertiary: Solar Energy International Progress. Proceedings of the International Symposium-Workshop on Solar Energy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Local and average heat transfer coefficients for natural convection between parallel plates, parallel plates with slats forming small aspect ratio enclosures, and a vee-corrugated plate with a parallel flat plate have been experimentally studied using interferometric techniques. The experimental conditions are similar to those existing in solar collectors. The results are useful in determining the top convective loss coefficient and therefore in minimizing losses and optimizing the design of solar collectors. The results indicate that the convective losses are strong functions of the aspect ratio for aspect ratios less than 4. Slat angles less than 90° help to reduce convective losses. The convective losses for a vee-corrugated surface are higher than those for a flat plate
z:row.User2: vee-corrugated solar collectors; heat transfer coefficients; natural convection; interferometric techniques; convective loss coefficient; aspect ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: CONVECTIVE HEAT TRANSFER IN TROUGH AND C. P. C. COLLECTORS
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the Annual Meeting - American Section of the International Solar Energy Society
z:row.Publisher: Am Sect of Int Sol Energy Soc, Inc, Newark, DelUSA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison, USA
z:row.Abstract: Natural convection heat-transfer coefficients have been experimentally determined for trough-type collectors. The effects of Rayleigh number, tilt angle, and ideal concentration ratio on the Nusselt number have been experimentally determined over ranges representative of collector operation. The convective losses are compared to those from conventional flat plate collectors. These results are useful to designers of collectors of this type, and allow estimation of the thermal losses during operation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Film boiling and vapor explosions from small spheres
z:row.TitleSecondary: 25th Annual Meeting of the American Nuclear Society, 3-7 June 1979
z:row.Keyword: boiling|fission reactor cooling and heat recovery|fission reactor safety
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Transactions of the American Nuclear Society
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Experimental and analytical studies of free-convection film-boiling heat transfer and its relation to vapor explosions are reported. The purpose of the work lies in the fact that film boiling has recently become an important consideration in nuclear reactor safety analysis
z:row.User2: small spheres; film boiling; nuclear reactor safety analysis; vapour explosions; film boiling heat transfer

z:row.TitlePrimary: NATURAL CONVECTION HEAT TRANSFER IN MODERATE ASPECT RATIO ENCLOSURES
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Heat Transfer, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: Local and average heat transfer coefficients for natural convection between parallel plates separated by slats to create enclosures of moderate aspect ratio have been experimentally determined using an interferometric technique. The effects of Rayleigh number, tilt and slat angle, and aspect ratio on the Nusselt number have been determined. The results indicate that the convective heat transfer is a strong function of the aspect ratio for aspect ratios less than 4. For aspect ratios in the range of 0. 5 to 4, spacers between the plates increase, rather than decrease, natural convection heat transfer compared to that for long enclosures. Slat angles less than 90 deg (i. e. , oriented downward) reduce convective heat transfer.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Natural convection heat transfer characteristics of flat plate enclosures
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Transactions of the ASME.Journal of Heat Transfer
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Mech. & Nuclear Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Heat transfer by natural convection in rectangular enclosures has been experimentally studied using interferometric techniques. The effects of Grashof number, tilt angle, and aspect ratio on both the local and average heat transfer coefficients have been determined
z:row.User2: flat plate enclosures; natural convection; interferometric techniques; Grashof number; tilt angle; aspect ratio

z:row.TitlePrimary: NONEQUILIBRIUM SUPERHEAT-SUBCOOLING OF LIQUIDS UNDER SUDDEN DEPRESSURIZATION
z:row.TitleSecondary: Two-phase Momentum, Heat and Mass Transfer in Chem, Process, and Energy Eng Syst, Pap Presented at the Semin of the Int Cent for Heat and Mass Transfer, Sep 4-9 1978
z:row.Keyword: FLOW OF FLUIDS|INTERFEROMETRY|NUCLEAR REACTORS, PRESSURIZED WATER - Loss Of Coolant Accident
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wis, Madison
z:row.Abstract: The behavior of a subcooled quiescent liquid layer undergoing sudden depressurization was examined experimentally using a Mach-Zehnder interferometer and high-speed photography. The resulting superheated liquid was seen to undergo an initial mode of instability consisting of small indentations on the liquid surface. Large rates of evaporation subsequently caused cold liquid globules to descend into the warmer liquid below. The minimum temperature from these globules was found to correspond closely to the saturation temperature at twice the pressure drop imposed. In one run, for example, Freon-11, initially at near atmospheric pressure, 98. 4 kPa, and 20. 8 degree C was suddenly depressurized to 79 kPa, corresponding to 3. 8 degree C superheat with the minimum temperature recorded as being 7. 8 degree C, corresponding to 9. 2 degree C subcooling. The critical time-dependent Rayleigh Number was found to be around 100, showing buoyancy as a possible cause for the instability.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental investigation of the helium I two-phase flow pressure drop characteristics in vertical tubes
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the Seventh International Cryogenic Engineering Conference, 4-7 July 1978
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the Seventh International Cryogenic Engineering Conference
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The authors describe experimental studies carried out on two-phase helium flowing in the upward direction in smooth vertical tubes. Two-phase pressure drops are measured at different adiabatic and diabatic flow conditions. The void fraction is measured at the tube exit with a capacitance probe. The two-phase friction multiplier is found to increase with the increase of vapor quality and to decrease with the increase of pressure or mass velocity with no significant tube size effect
z:row.User2: diabatic flow conditions; void fraction; capacitance probe; 2-phase flow pressure drop; He I; adiabatic flow; 2-phase friction multiplier

z:row.TitlePrimary: An interferometric investigation of heat transfer in honeycomb solar collector cells
z:row.TitleSecondary: Sun: Mankind's future source of energy, Jan. 1978
z:row.TitleTertiary: Sun: Mankind's future source of energy
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Mech. Engng. Dept., Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Local and average heat transfer coefficients for natural convection between parallel plates via honeycomb cells have been studied using an interferometric technique. The experimental conditions are similar to those proposed for honeycomb solar collectors. Nusselt numbers were obtained experimentally for collector tilt angles of 60° and 90°, and various Grashof numbers and aspect ratios. This study also proposes varying the honeycomb angle (with respect to the plates) from the conventional 90°, and honeycomb angles of 90° and 60° are studied. The results are useful in determining the top convective loss coefficient, and therefore in minimizing losses and optimizing the design
z:row.User2: solar collector; heat transfer coefficients; natural convection; parallel plates; honeycomb cells; interferometric technique; Nusselt numbers; Grashof numbers; aspect ratios; honeycomb angle; losses; design

z:row.TitlePrimary: Free convection heat transfer to supercritical helium
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 6th International Cryogenic Engineering Conference, 11-14 May 1976
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 6th International Cryogenic Engineering Conference
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Supercritical helium as a coolant may be forced to flow through conduits or channels and heat is transferred by free or forced convection. Free convection will be the predominant heat transfer mechanism for Gr/Re2⩾1, where Gr and Re are the Grashof and Reynolds numbers, respectively. Even for Reynolds numbers of 105, such conditions can be easily reached with supercritical helium because of the large thermal expansivities and the small kinematic viscosities encountered. For large conduits and reasonable flow rates of supercritical helium, it can be seen that the heat transfer will be mainly by free convection. The study of cryogenic free convective heat transfer from a sphere to supercritical helium is reported
z:row.User2: free convection heat transfer; supercritical He; 4.2 to 25K; 3 to 35 atm

z:row.TitlePrimary: Heat transfer and fluid flow in porous fuel elements and thermal shields
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The heat-transfer and fluid-flow problem in porous nuclear fuel elements and thermal shields is investigated. Porous fuel elements of flat-plate and hollow-cylindrical types are compared to conventional surface-cooled non-porous fuel elements. The comparison shows that porous elements result in much lower fuel temperatures for the same specific power or much higher specific powers for the same temperatures. The study also indicates that porous materials subjected to radiation operate at much lower temperatures and temperature gradients than non-porous materials when used as thermal shields
z:row.User2: heat transfer; fluid flow; porous fuel elements; thermal shields

z:row.TitlePrimary: An interferometric technique for measuring binary diffusion coefficients
z:row.TitleTertiary: Trans. ASME, C, J. Heat Transf. (USA)
z:row.PeriodicalAbbrev: Transactions of the ASME.Series C, Journal of Heat Transfer
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ. Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An accurate interferometric technique for the measurement of Fick binary diffusion coefficients is described. The technique employs a Mach-Zehnder interferometer together with a high-speed stroboscope and flash-tube light source and a drum camera as a recording system. Successive concentration profiles are recorded in a modified, transient, one-dimensional Arnold diffusion model. A relative-time, relative-position method is used to analyze the interferograms, thus eliminating the uncertainties regarding the absolute diffusion time and exact position above the liquid surface in the diffusion cell as well as the overall mass transfer rate. This technique yields experimental values of the diffusion coefficient with an estimated accuracy of 1/2 percent and reproducibility of approximately ±1 percent. The binary diffusion coefficients for ten materials, four polar and six nonpolar, diffusing in air are presented. Of these, five have been studied by other investigators. The other five have not been previously reported in the literature
